content: The Act titled "Anti-Atrocity Alien Deportation Act of 2003" addresses the inadmissibility and deportability of aliens who have committed acts of torture or extrajudicial killings abroad. The Act "Anti-Atrocity Alien Deportation Act of 2003" amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to make aliens who have committed acts of torture or extrajudicial killings outside the United States inadmissible. The Act "Anti-Atrocity Alien Deportation Act of 2003" makes aliens who have committed acts of torture or extrajudicial killings outside the United States inadmissible. The Act "Anti-Atrocity Alien Deportation Act of 2003" makes aliens who have committed acts of torture or extrajudicial killings outside the United States inadmissible, including participation in nazi persecution, genocide, or the commission of any act of torture or extrajudicial killing. Amendments to the Act expand the scope of deportability to include participation in nazi persecution, genocide, or the commission of any act of torture or extrajudicial killing. These amendments apply to offenses committed before, on, or after the date of the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. Inadmissibility and deportability of foreign government officials who have committed severe violations of religious freedom. Foreign government officials who have committed particularly severe violations of religious freedom are inadmissible under the Immigration and Nationality Act. Additionally, any alien who participated in the commission of severe violations of religious freedom is deportable. Any alien described in section 212(a)(2)(G) is deportable for violations of religious freedom. SEC. 4. Waiver of inadmissibility is amended in the Immigration and Nationality Act. SEC. 5. Bar to good moral character for aliens who have committed acts of torture, extrajudicial killings, or severe violations of religious freedom. Section 101(f) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include individuals who have engaged in conduct related to Nazi persecution, genocide, torture, extrajudicial killings, or severe violations of religious freedom. Additionally, the establishment of the Office of Special Investigations is mentioned. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to establish an Office of Special Investigations within the Department of Justice to denaturalize aliens involved in specific criminal activities. The Attorney General will collaborate with the Department of Homeland Security on legal actions against these individuals. Consideration will be given to potential criminal prosecution under U.S. laws for relevant conduct. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to establish an Office of Special Investigations within the Department of Justice to denaturalize aliens involved in specific criminal activities. Appropriations are authorized to ensure the Office fulfills its obligations regarding Nazi war criminals. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, must submit a report to Congress within 180 days detailing procedures for referring cases to relevant departments, revisions to immigration forms reflecting changes in the law, and processes for gathering evidence to determine admissibility of aliens under the new amendments. An alien may be inadmissible under the amendments made by this Act.
